jdm.name: Facebook
jdm.notes: While you can delete your account easily, some of the data including messages, are there to stay forever, just as stated in the website's privacy policy.

points.title: This service tracks you on other websites

tosdr.tldr: This service uses cookies to track you even if you are not interacting with them directly. Information gathered about you could include: date and time you visit the site; the web address or URL you're on; technical information about the IP address, browser and the operating system you use; and, if you are logged in to the service at the same time, your user ID.

topics.description: Cookies are files stored locally in your web browser containing identifiable information.

points.title: You can give your feedback before changes

tosdr.tldr: Ordinarily, Facebook will provide 7 days’ advance notice of changes by posting on the Facebook Site Governance Page. You can respond to changes by posting your comments, but there is no guarantee this will impact the proposed change.

topics.description: The terms are a contract between two parties, and it should not be changed unilaterally without consultation of the other party. Services should listen to what their users say and care about, and give them a vote in each substantial change.

points.title: No promise to inform you about data requests from governments

tosdr.tldr: The service has made no promise to inform users a government request for their data has been made. As it's unlikely you'd know about the request, you'd have no real opportunity to object to the request being made or carried out.

points.title: Very broad copyright license on your content

tosdr.tldr: The copyright licence is very broad. It includes the right for Facebook share your content with others. Depending on your Facebook Privacy and Application settings, this could apply to your photos and videos. Facebook's right to do this under the licence does not end when you stop using the service either, unless your content has been deleted by everyone else.

topics.description: Copyright law gives you control over how your content (texts, photos, videos, etc.) can be used, by whom they can be distributed, modified, etc. Sometimes, online services need your permission to perform certain tasks with your content. That's why they ask you to grant them a copyright license. But sometimes, the copyright license is so broad, that your content can be exploited by others without asking you.

tosdr.case: pseudonym not allowed (not because of user-to-user trust)
tosdr.tldr: You must use your legal name publicly on this service. Using a pseudonym or a pen name is not allowed. This can negatively impact your freedom of expression, especially for those with certain professions, or who live in certain countries.

topics.description: The terms sometimes describe the level of logging and the level of data collection and which kinds of data the service is processing. Anonymity or the right to use a pseudonym can be very important for freedom of expression (e.g. for people exercising a certain profession, or people living in authoritarian regimes).

points.title: Facebook automatically shares your data with many other services

tosdr.case: many third parties are involved in operating the service
tosdr.tldr: Facebook automatically shares your information with companies like Bing, Pandora, TripAdvisor, Yelp, Rotten Tomatoes, Clicker, Scribd, and Docs, unless you manually opt-out.
